title: EasyJet strike averted after pay deal reached
text:
Save 
A summer strike threatened by easyJet cabin crew has been averted, after airline staff accepted a pay deal. 
The deal was agreed yesterday, with 2,000 cabin crew voting to accept the combined pay proposal, which included the recent two year pay award of 4.1% for cabin crew and 5.1% for cabin managers backdated to January 2015. 
They have also been awarded an increase in the holiday pay allowance for all cabin crew. Unite members voted by 52% to 48% to accept the improved offer. 
The Unite union warned bosses that the revised deal should serve as a “wake-up call”. 
Unite regional officer Kevin Hall said: “While we are pleased that the dispute is settled and there will be no disruption for those jetting away on their summer holidays, this dispute is a wake-up call to the management. 
“The company needs to start smelling the coffee about the pay and conditions of its staff that emerged during this dispute when it comes to future pay claims. This highly profitable company got away with a settlement by the skin of its teeth.” 
Unite cabin crew operate from 11 UK bases: Belfast, Bristol, Edinburgh, Gatwick, Glasgow, Liverpool, Luton, Manchester, Newcastle upon Tyne, Southend andStansted. 
In a statement easyJet added: “EasyJet values the contribution its cabin crew make and is pleased to have reached a positive conclusion so that its crew can continue to provide the excellent, friendly service our passengers expect and they can have complete reassurance that their travel plans will not be disrupted this summer.” Readers' comments (1) race welch | Tue, 4 Aug 2015 12:05 pm 
This is indeed great news for the cabin crew and their customers, however, you can see the bully boy tactics are still securely in place by the likes of Unite who have the loony left as their voice of threats and confrontation continues.
